pr_title: Initial commit of step and timestep support for data retrieval

timeline.message: Initial commit of step and timestep support for data retrieval
Added unconditional seek when applying timestep
Refactored to introduce FetchRequest to simplify signatures
Added support for step/timestep/sample/skip in SlicedRowFilterGTSDecoderIterator
Disabled use of filter when fetching by count with step/timestep/skip/sample
Added support for advanced fetch parameters in Warp10InputFormat

timeline.bodyText: 1 is a valid value, although it does nothing different than not specifying step at all.
timeline.author: ftence

timeline.bodyText: 1 is valid.
timeline.author: ftence
ftence

timeline.bodyText:
Update the javadoc to reflect that this function takes only one parameter, leaving the description of its fields.
Also change then to thents.
timeline.author: ftence
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -36,13 +35,15 @@
    * @param then Start timestamp (included)
    * @param count Number of datapoints to fetch. 0 is a valid value if you want to fetch only boundaries. Use -1 to specify you are not fetching by count.
    * @param skip Number of datapoints to skip before returning values
+   * @param step Index offset between two datapoints, defaults to 1, i.e. return every data point
+   * @param timestep Minimum time offset between datapoints, defaults to 1 time unit
    * @param sample Double value representing the sampling rate. Use 1.0D for returning all values. Valid values are ] 0.0D, 1.0D ]
    * @param writeTimestamp Flag indicating we are interested in the HBase cell timestamp
    * @param preBoundary Size of the pre boundary in number of values
    * @param postBoundary Size of the post boundary in number of values
    * @return
    * @throws IOException
    */
-  public GTSDecoderIterator fetch(ReadToken token, final List<Metadata> metadatas, final long now, final long then, long count, long skip, double sample, boolean writeTimestamp, final long preBoundary, final long postBoundary) throws IOException;
+  public GTSDecoderIterator fetch(FetchRequest req) throws IOException; //ReadToken token, final List<Metadata> metadatas, final long now, final long then, long count, long skip, long step, long timestep, double sample, boolean writeTimestamp, final long preBoundary, final long postBoundary) throws IOException;

timeline.bodyText:
You should factorize the FetchRequest construction, making sure to use the copy constructor.
Only preBoundary, postBoundary, step, timestep, sample, skip and count may have been modified, so setting the other fields after the copy constructor is not necessary.
timeline.author: ftence

timeline.bodyText: Initialize it to 0L else the first this.request.getStep() - 1 will be stepped over.
timeline.author: ftence

timeline.bodyText:
Do that only if encoder.size() > 0 ie. move that in the if few lines below.
This one is tricky and took me a lot of time to debug:
If encoder has empty metadata (first metadata in the list) it is considered as a change of metadata. Thus it will not trigger the return in the if below and result will be processed. However, result will be also stored in pendingresult so it will be reprocessed, resulting in duplicate datapoints in the resulting decoder.
timeline.author: ftence

replies.bodyText: Comment is for line this.pendingresult = result;, GitHub messed this up.
replies.author: ftence
